General provisions

" "
Chess is played by two players on a board with 64 black and white cells, white and black pieces. A chessboard is usually called a chessboard. The chessboard is placed in such a way that its first horizontal is near the player playing white. At the same time, the rightmost corner field h1 must be white. Each player has 16 chess pieces: eight pawns, two rooks, two knights, two bishops, a queen and a king. Players make moves in turn. During each turn, a player can move only one piece. An exception is castling — a joint move of rook and king. The game begins with the player playing with white pieces. When moving your piece to a cell occupied by an opponent's piece, the opponent's piece is removed from the board. Such a move is called taking.

" "
Rules for moving pieces

" "
• Pawn — moves forward only vertically. The first move of a pawn — white from the second, and black from the seventh horizontal — can be made two cells at once, jumping over the third or sixth horizontal. From all other horizontals, the pawn can only move one cell forward. In addition, the pawn can take any piece of the opponent that is in front of him at a distance of one cell diagonally. If the white pawn has reached the eighth horizontal, or the black one — the first, then it can turn into any piece (except the king) of the same color as the pawn.

" "
• Rook — moves any number of cells vertically or horizontally.

" "
• Knight — is the only piece in the game that can jump over other pieces — its own and the opponent's. The knight's move is similar to the letter \"L\". The knight moves one cell vertically and two horizontally, or vice versa — two vertically and one horizontally in any direction.

" "
• Bishop — moves any number of cells diagonally.

" "
• King — moves one cell vertically, horizontally or diagonally, or two if it is a castling.

" "
• Queen — moves any number of cells vertically, horizontally or diagonally.

" "
Some chess terms

" "
Check — is a position in which the king of the player whose turn it is to make a move is under attack by the opponent's pieces.

" "
Checkmate — is a check against which there is no defense. The player who checkmate the opponent's king wins the game.

" "
Castling — is a move in chess in which the king is moved from his initial position across one cell horizontally with the simultaneous movement of the rook to this cell. Castling is performed as follows: the king moves horizontally two cells. At the same time, the rook is set on the cell through which the king jumped, that is, the king is behind the rook with which he castled. Castling is considered the king's move and the player must move the king first, and then the rook. In chess notation, a short rook is written as \"0-0\", a long one is \"0-0-0\"

" "
Win, draw

" "
The game is declared won by one of the opponents if:

" "
• Checkmate is announced to the opponent's king.

" "
• The opponent declared himself defeated.

" "
A game is declared a draw if:

" "
• By mutual consent of the players.
